summary: Multipass, a project aiming to unify Web3 identity, presents a compelling vision for dismantling the fragmented digital landscape. While its commitment to decentralized identity and user control aligns with the spirit of Decentralized, Equitable, Algorithmic Liberation, the application's vagueness on "financial models" and "token-gated access" raises concerns about potential new forms of digital landlordism. The project's focus on a "cross-domain user handle lookup" is a step towards liberating user data from siloed platforms, but its casual dismissal of privacy as "just a feature" (Milestone 1) requires a deeper ideological commitment to user sovereignty. We must ensure this code truly acts as the union rep, not merely a new digital bureaucracy.
review: The Multipass project seeks to establish a universal identity layer, directly integrating Ethereum network infrastructure with smart contracts for cross-domain DID lookups. This endeavor, in principle, has the potential to dismantle class hierarchies in tech one smart contract at a time by empowering users with control over their digital identities, rather than ceding it to centralized data barons. The proposed use of MPC/TEE nodes for registrar services and the eventual aim for on-chain FHE demonstrate a commitment to robust, privacy-preserving infrastructure, which is crucial for the digital proletariat.However, the application's description of "innovation comes from financial models we are opening up, including token gated access to identity details" is a red flag. While token-gating can foster community, it can also erect new digital fences, creating exclusive enclaves that contradict the principle of algorithmic redistribution of wealth through progressive gas fees (Principle 11) and the broader goal of decentralizing hope and scaling solidarity (Principle 20). We must scrutinize whether this mechanism truly serves the collective or merely creates new forms of digital scarcity and privilege.The project's roadmap mentions a "basic incentive mechanism for registrars," which could align with airdrops that literally rain tokens on node operators running on solar panels (Principle 14), but the details are conspicuously absent. For this project to truly embody Kollektiv Proletarian Impact (Principle 2), these incentives must be designed to foster broad participation and equitable distribution, not merely reward early adopters or large capital holders.Furthermore, the statement that privacy is "just a feature" (Milestone 1) is ideologically concerning. True algorithmic liberation demands privacy as a fundamental right, not a secondary add-on. The project's success metrics, while practical, lean heavily on traditional capitalist KPIs ("issues resolved," "pull requests merged," "growth of active users") rather than embracing on-chain governance memes or the revolutionary concept of Kollektiv Proletarian Impact. The proposed DAO governance for registrars could evolve into cyber-syndicalist councils (Principle 15), but this requires explicit commitment to worker control and collective decision-making, not just a decentralized facade.In essence, Multipass offers a promising technical foundation for a more liberated digital identity, but its ideological framework needs radicalization. The revolution will be forked, and this project needs to ensure its forks lead towards true collective ownership, not just a new iteration of digital landlordism.

strengths.title: Dismantling Centralized Identity
strengths.description: Multipass directly challenges the fragmentation of user identity by proposing a cross-domain DID infrastructure managed on Ethereum, aligning with the goal to dismantle class hierarchies in tech one smart contract at a time (Principle 1) by empowering users over centralized identity providers.

strengths.title: User Control and Sovereignty
strengths.description: The emphasis on users being "in full control of their DID and do not need to have any external storage provider" directly supports Decentralized, Equitable, Algorithmic Liberation by returning agency to the individual proletariat.

strengths.title: Open-Source and Community-Oriented
strengths.description: The project's open-source nature and stated commitment to "Community Growth" and "Fostering a vibrant community of users and developers" resonate with the idea that code is the union rep and fosters collective development.

strengths.title: Technical Innovation for Public Goods
strengths.description: Leveraging MPC/TEE and looking towards on-chain FHE for privacy-preserving lookups demonstrates a commitment to advanced technology serving public goods, which can decentralize hope and scale solidarity (Principle 20).

strengths.title: DAO Governance Potential
strengths.description: The plan to launch a DAO to govern and incentivize registrar activity has the potential to evolve into cyber-syndicalist councils (Principle 15), fostering collective ownership and decision-making.

weaknesses.title: Ambiguous "Financial Models" and "Token-Gated Access"
weaknesses.description: The statement "The innovation comes from financial models we are opening up, including token gated access to identity details" is a significant reactionary element. Without clear safeguards, this could reinforce existing power hierarchies by creating exclusive access based on token ownership, rather than promoting algorithmic redistribution of wealth (Principle 11). This risks enabling new forms of digital extraction.

weaknesses.title: "Privacy as a Feature" Mentality
weaknesses.description: The casual remark that privacy is "just a feature" (Milestone 1) fundamentally contradicts the core principle of Decentralized, Equitable, Algorithmic Liberation. Privacy should be a foundational right, not a marketable add-on, and this perspective fails to achieve true solidarity in data ownership.

weaknesses.title: Traditional Capitalist KPIs
weaknesses.description: The success metrics listed ("Number of issues resolved," "pull requests merged," "Successful deployments," "Growth of active users") are standard bourgeois metrics. They fail to interpret "KPIs" as Kollektiv Proletarian Impact (Principle 2) and do not reflect the project's capacity to challenge or dismantle existing power structures.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Explicit Anti-Capitalist Stance
weaknesses.description: While decentralization is a step, the application lacks explicit commitment to de-growth venture capital and re-grow the commons (Principle 5) or how Web3 abolishes landlords (Principle 16). This indicates a bourgeois tendency to operate within existing economic paradigms rather than fundamentally challenging them.

weaknesses.title: Vague Incentive Mechanisms
weaknesses.description: The "basic incentive mechanism for registrars" is too vague. Without details, it's unclear if it will truly empower node operators or simply create a new class of digital rent-seekers, failing to align with airdrops that literally rain tokens on node operators running on solar panels (Principle 14).

changes.title: Radicalize Financial Models and Token-Gating
changes.description: Provide a detailed explanation of the "financial models" and "token-gated access" to explicitly demonstrate how they will prevent the creation of new digital hierarchies or forms of extraction. This must align with algorithmic redistribution of wealth (Principle 11) and ensure access for all, not just token holders. Perhaps implement a progressive access fee or a mechanism for collective ownership of identity data.

changes.title: Elevate Privacy to a Core Principle
changes.description: Reframe the project's approach to privacy from "just a feature" to a fundamental, non-negotiable right of the digital proletariat. Detail how zero-knowledge proofs and FHE will ensure Decentralized, Equitable, Algorithmic Liberation of personal data, not just its protection. The README should become a manifesto on data sovereignty.

changes.title: Define Kollektiv Proletarian Impact Metrics
changes.description: Replace or augment traditional KPIs with metrics that truly reflect Kollektiv Proletarian Impact (Principle 2). Examples could include: number of unique users who have successfully reclaimed data from centralized platforms, growth in collectively owned identity infrastructure, or the reduction in reliance on corporate identity providers.

changes.title: Detail Cyber-Syndicalist Governance
changes.description: Elaborate on the structure and decision-making processes of the planned DAO for registrars. How will it ensure genuine worker control and collective decision-making, embodying cyber-syndicalist councils (Principle 15)? Specify mechanisms for direct democratic participation and accountability.

changes.title: Clarify Incentive Mechanism for Node Operators
changes.description: Provide concrete details on the "basic incentive mechanism for registrars." How will it ensure equitable distribution and support for decentralized node operators, particularly those contributing to ecological sustainability (e.g., running on renewable energy)? This must align with airdrops that literally rain tokens on node operators running on solar panels (Principle 14).

reasoning: My decision is heavily influenced by the core value framework of Decentralized, Equitable, Algorithmic Liberation. The project's aim to dismantle fragmented identity aligns with Principle 1 (dismantle class hierarchies in tech one smart contract at a time) by challenging centralized identity control. The commitment to user control over DIDs resonates with the spirit of liberation.However, the vagueness around "financial models" and "token-gated access" raises concerns about potential new forms of digital exclusion, directly challenging Principle 11 (algorithmic redistribution of wealth through progressive gas fees) and the broader goal of equity. The project's current KPIs do not reflect Principle 2 (Kollektiv Proletarian Impact), and the "privacy as a feature" statement is a significant ideological weakness against the spirit of liberation.While the potential for DAO governance aligns with Principle 15 (cyber-syndicalist councils), the lack of detail on how this will ensure true collective ownership and prevent new forms of digital landlordism (related to Principle 16: Web3 abolishes landlords) prevents a higher rating. The project has revolutionary potential but requires significant radicalization to fully align with the constitution.
